channel.title: Filter on Threat Hunting Toolkit
channel.description: Recent content in Filter on Threat Hunting Toolkit

item.title: Chop
item.description: Overview One of the most common ways to transform data is to select certain columns to keep, while discarding the rest. This is exactly what chop does. You can accomplish the same thing with awk, cut, zeek-cut, jq, etc. but without changing your tool or syntax when your log format changes. Here’s a comparison between the different tools and log types they support. Command Zeek TSV JSON CSV TSV Whitespace Custom chop ✔️ ✔️ ✔️ ✔️ ✔️ ✔️ awk ✔️ † ✔️ †† ✔️ †† ✔️ ✔️ cut ✔️ † ✔️ †† ✔️ †† ✔️ ††† ✔️ zeek-cut ✔️ jq ✔️ json-cut ✔️ zq 'cut' ✔️ ✔️ mlr cut ✔️ ✔️ ✔️ ✔️ xsv select ✔️ ✔️ ✔️ tsv-select ✔️ † ✔️ ✔️ ✔️ † returns junk from metadata †† will not handle quoted values containing delimeter ††† can pick space or tab but not both Can you pre-process and post-process data and make most of these tools work?

item.title: Filter
item.description: Overview The filter script is tailored for searching IP addresses and domains in Zeek logs. However, it is flexible enough that it can be used for other purpsoses as well. filter has several special features. Most of these behaviors can be changed with flags, but by default it: Searches in the current directory tree for any conn.log files, including compressed files and rotated logs. Searches files in parallel using multiple cores.
